this AWS webinar series on expanding your data center with hybrid infrastructure my name is Richard Busby
I'm an ecosystem solution architect with Amazon Web Services based on going to New Zealand and over the next 45 minutes
or so we'll be taking you through an introductory level topic about expanding
your data center using AWS in conjunction with your data center and the benefits that that brings so let's
start by asking a fairly simple question about what is hybrid IT Gartner provide
a really helpful definition here which is the hybrid IT is the result of combining internal and external services
from a combination of internal and public clouds in support of a business outcome and these are really quite
important terms if you think about it you need to start thinking about your hybrid IT environment in terms of
services that you're going to consume from both internal and external and how
you're going to use a combination of those services to deliver business outcomes one of the things that we often
find customers doing in their journey through hybrid cloud is evaluating the
performance functionality differences etc between public clouds and their own
internal IT environments and assessing which if their workloads are going to be
most suited to run in each environment [Music] so why do we want to look at hybrid IT
the simple reason is that a lot of you have existing investments today in your own data center and your on-premise
solutions and you need to continue to be able to capitalize on those while also realizing the benefits that the AWS
cloud can can give you some of those common benefits are things like scalability it's much easier to scale on
the AWS cloud than it is to do so in your own data center in many many cases security
awwe us works very very hard to achieve and maintain a number of different
security and industry compliance certifications and these are things that
are of benefit every single AWS car we're out there so we're really it makes
it very easy for you to achieve those benefits in the AWS cloud for workloads
that require certain compliance or security certifications AWS is also a
durable and highly available sin a platform so you can put applications on
the AWS cloud and be assured that for example your data is going to be there for a long long period of time it's
going to be very durable stored and you can architect applications on the AWS
cloud to be very very highly available AWS also gives you a lot of agility we
have a number of tools some of which we'll talk about today and some of which we won't that enable you to rapidly
deploy applications out to AWS enable you to template those deploy them
multiple times revision them change them very very easily another reason that we
see people starting to look at the aw this cloud is global reach so I have customers in New Zealand for example one
of those is a company called erode and erode are a road user charging organizations so they put things in
trucks and cabs around the world that record where a user is traveling or
where a trucks going and they need to be able to do that all over the world and then report on that for customers all

you know Sydney or wherever is difficult it's much much easier for them to be able to go global by adopting or
adapting to AWS deploying their applications out across multiple physical facilities all across the world
in getting very close to their customers another reason that people often look at
AWS is the breadth of services so we'll talk about some services today we have
around 45 different services now the cover a range of different use cases from real-time analysis to Internet of
Things to war compute power to storage to administration and deployment and
being able to consume those services quickly easily and as a pay on a pay-as-you-go basis can often be a lot

a number of common hybrid workloads that we see customers adopting when they're on the hybrid journey with AWS the first
of those is backup and archive this is a very easy way to get started in a hybrid
environment hybrid cloud using existing backup software that you may have in
your environment using existing archiving software that you have in your own fireman and and rather than

AWS but with a really minimal change to the way you continue to run and operate

and technologies and gain benefit very very quickly another common use case is
disaster recovery we often see people who have a single site they have
everything in one site and they're looking at disaster recovery disaster recovery is often a very complex and
expensive undertaking for many customers you have to have a second site it has to be tier dispersed from your first site
for example a lot of the time when you have that disaster recovery site you
spent a lot of time and effort money creating it and configuring it only to find that most of the time you're not
using it because you're not suffering from a disaster by using AWS as a disaster recovery target you only pay
for what you use the majority of the time you use very few or no resources they cost you any money but you can have
a templated automatically deployables featured disaster recovery sites set up
AWS that can be up and going within minutes or hours after a major disaster

looking at what new things can we do by leveraging the power of the AWS cloud

very difficult to to write a business case for to get going with because it's

virtual private cloud is a way of extending your data center and carving
out a private network portion of your cloud for your use so the way this looks
is you can create your own like I say isolated section of the AWS cloud you
can bring your own IP address space to this notice the example here we've got

that need to get out to the internet then you'll have an Internet gateway at the top there allowing those systems to
